Jared Kushner’s family business ties to Citigroup and Apollo Global Management are more extensive than initially reported, Democratic lawmakers said on Friday.
Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, Tom Carper of Delaware, and Gary Peters of Michigan, and Rep. Elijah Cummings of Maryland, ranking member of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee.
“The Kushner family has been a client of Citi for decades,” and a March 31, 2017, loan to the family was “completely appropriate,” Citi’s general counsel, Rohan Weerasinghe, wrote .
Kushner Companies is more than $600 million in debt to Citi and owes Apollo more than $250 million, the lawmakers said, releasing letters from the two companies.
The purpose of the meeting was to discuss trade policy, “given Mr. Kushner’s leadership role in the NAFTA negotiations,” Citi wrote in a letter to lawmakers.
Kushner also met several times last year with Apollo co-founder Joshua Harris just months before Kushner Companies closed on a $184 million loan with Apollo.

In letters to the companies on Friday, lawmakers asked for more detail on the companies’ financial ties to Kushner.
“Josh Harris and Jared Kushner never discussed any loans to Kushner Companies,” a lawyer for Apollo wrote in the March 20 letter .
The loans were originated around the time Kushner was named a senior adviser to President Donald Trump, his father-in-law.
“To our knowledge Jared Kushner did not play any role on behalf of Kushner Companies” with respect to the loan.
Kushner sat down with Citi’s chief executive, Michael Corbat, on March 3, 2017, at Corbat’s request.
